text: There are some serious data governance issues with Agentic AIs that a lot of companies are missing and also some up front CapitalX expenses/business process uplifts that most of those looking for one of these solutions are not aware of. For example, I worked with a SMB restaurant to make a front-of-house booking agent that would interact with people on social media, take phone calls, inform potential customers of menu options and health concerns (peanut allergies, vegan food choices, etc), and do basic bookings. Unfortunately, the customer didn't know what internal business tasks needed to be done before they could really onboard an AI Agent. The customer didn't have an up-to-date menu online and the head chef would routinely switch out meals or do specials/deals based on things that suppliers had. The phone line to the company was not able to be re-routed into a cloud environment or online system to provide the necessary hooks for the agent, and the company didn't have a good way of documenting electronically what items might be exposed to different allergies. These issues were overcome but should just stand as a warning for anyone that is hoping that an Agentic AI system can be directly dropped into an existing environment with no uplift from other stakeholders or of business processes. This also is ignoring the entire issue of having an Agentic AI solution that does not process data in house and instead sends that data to an agent (say OpenAI's ChatGPT) for processing as part of a pipeline. If you have proprietary company data, PII data, PCI data, HIPAA data, or any other regulated data types (or you have regional regulation requirements that are applicable to your company, such as GDPR restricted data/responsibilities) you will have more hoops to jump through and more stops added onto your journey to establish an internal Agentic AI system.

Zig Serafin's comments are typical of the techno-optimists. Unfortunately they don't match the data in most instances. The argument that technology will remove the routine, often administrative work suggests that this only provides negatives and is devoid of any benefit. This isn't correct. Having some time doing a task which you can do without being intellectually taxed enables a degree of mental rest. Remove it and you take away mental 'down time'. The technical terms for this is 'work intensity'. That is if the easy stuff is removed, what is left is hard, demanding stuff even if the techno-optimists might call it 'creative work'. Increasing work intensity is linked with increased stress, mental health issues, burnout and ultimately lower productivity. Workers with increased work intensity often seek to restore their work-life-balance, for example through fewer days working. Many economies are showing increasing numbers of workers deciding to work part-time. Another key issue which hasn't been discussed is how AI is reducing the development opportunities of more junior staff. Often the tasks that are being automated are the very tasks that previously junior staff used to do to build experience. I'm not convinced organisations have considered fully the implications of this with long-term firm specific human capital development. I'm convinced that both of these can be mitigated, but those mitigation plans need to be considered and implemented when AI is introduced, and I don't see enough evidence of that happening.

What (currently almost) everyone REALLY fails to understand: In its current incarnation AI / AI-Agents feel clumsy and "interesting" at best. Yet: Models, Algorithms, and Training-methods are improving fast & constantly - (actually, on a weekly/monthly basis). (Large) Companies ARE (!) willing to open up their (internal) knowledge-basis to train Foundational Models - thus, giving these Models "Access" to Domain-Knowledge, which in turn is ESSENTIAL for Agentic-AI to work. This step-by-step improvement + constant innovation in LLMs + enormous (!!!) Datacenter constructions, currently happening in Virginia, Texas et al, are all the building blocks, necessary to drive this transformation. Once these DCs are in-place & up & running - there is enough Server- and Storage-Capacity to deploy Inference-Instances on High-quality - & Large-Volume-Scale. Then (we are mostly talking about: late 2025-2026) Agentic-AI will hit us like a Tsunami. And once this happens, all the nice "Talk" about shift of workforce into inter-social related jobs will also be meaningless, because there will not be ENOUGH people to talk to (or work with) for those who were lucky enough to keep their jobs....Eventually all the FOMO-driven CEOs will understand, that even THEIR work can be (and will be) executed by an AI. Everything "executable" is designed for being replaced by an AI. Why should the work of a Chief EXECUTIVE (!!!) Officer be exempt from this logic ????. Add to this shift another dimension, namely: gradual deployment of embodied-AI (i.e. Autonomous Cars, (Humanoid)-Robotics, Smart-Home-Devices, Body-Augmentation (Watches, Glasses etc...) and voilá: We bridge the physical-digital gap by incorporating these Bu*****t into our physical reality - providing them with constant (real-time) sensory-data. Where is a place left for human beings ??? If we don´t pull the plug NOW (which we certainly WILL NOT - reasons being: capitalistic greed & FOMO) - we will become: Nice (human) animals to observe and manipulate in "A Zoo called: Earth"

Agentic AI isn’t just a “wind-up toy” — once given autonomy across platforms, a single mistake could trigger financial collapses, legal liabilities, or even chain-reaction failures across industries. Job loss won’t be limited to repetitive work; history shows automation climbs the ladder, eventually hollowing out creative and strategic roles too. “Agentic washing” makes it worse, luring companies into over-trusting unstable systems. Giving AI deep access to data and workflows risks massive leaks, manipulation, and cyberattacks at a scale humans can’t contain. The real danger isn’t that AI replaces drudgery — it’s that unchecked agentic systems destabilize jobs, economies, and institutions faster than society can adapt.

Large language models and multimodal transformers are actually more deterministic than most people realise. A certain input (“context”) maps into certain probability distribution. In other words, with a certain query, you always get certain probability distribution over the tokens. Then, if the temperature is set to zero, you get the same output token for a given input. (Some low level implementation details like GPU setting may need to support this… but I don’t think this aspect is realised by the stochastic parrot crowd). But it’s still “a black box”, to a large extent.

A Carnegie Mellon Universiy study "TheAgentCompany: Benchmarking LLM Agents on Consequential Real World Tasks" says that even the best-performing AI agent, Google's Gemini 2.5 Pro, failed to complete real-world office tasks 70 percent of the time. Factoring in partially completed tasks — which included work like responding to colleagues, web browsing, and coding — only brought Gemini's failure rate down to 61.7 percent. And the vast majority of its competing agents did substantially worse.

Plateaued? Arguably and based on evidence, not. Google’s IMO gold medal being a case in point. It’s an “order of magnitude jump”. I spent quite a while developing a model estimating how many people there are who could get a similar result (after 3-6 months preparation because it’s a kind of sport). Turns out, only one in 2 million people have this sort of ability. So, actually if we go back to GPT3 time, most adults in the UK would have had a way superior maths abilities to that model. People think the models have plateaued because 1) the average user does not have a demanding enough use case, and 2) the models are still brittle, in that they can still make occasionally silly mistakes. However, if you carefully look at the evidence, in many important domains, such as mathematics and coding, the models have not plateaued.

Apologies to all the skeptics. I have two companies, and both will be swept away by AI. The value of the second company is already only 1/10 of what it would be without AI. I don't want AI! But we have to be realistic. As I sit here and write this text, my AI bot is writing code at the speed of 2 or 3 very good developers. I can't code, but I understand code. That makes me a super developer. Thats just the begining. Software will be worth almost nothing in a few years. And anyone who thinks AI is stupid is wrong. AI is already smarter than almost every single one of us. The models are good and will get even better, but how the models are used, how they are structured, will change everything. A good developer, for example, is only as good as the system around them (project manager, designer, sprint planning ...). If the system stands for AI, then any software can be recreated in hours. Any company that currently relies on services or other digital IP can be replaced. And once the robots are here, there will be no more digital walls. The best outcome: we will all have time for interpersonal relationships again. The worst outcome: think for yourself.

These people are fools and this is utter nonsense and is a classic case of getting high off the GPU fumes wafting out of Nvidia's fabrication plant, all symptoms of the hype there is in this industry right now, to get as much money as they can, before the big bubble goes pop. Take this from someone on the ground researching in this area for a decade. Agents ARE NOT going to take your jobs. My PhD was on agent systems and state machines and it just makes me laugh my arse off around the nonsense put out there. Here is the big problem which has every tech giant stuck and spinning when it comes to agents: They cannot be debugged. What do I mean by that? With traditional software, when there is any sort of software bug, we use debuggers. We point in break points, which freeze the software in place, we can then observe the state of different variables, or if we wanted to, right down to memory allocation. You then fix that bug, and the system is healthy again. With Agents, this is impossible, utterly impossible. A large language model is completely non-deterministic; it will never have repeatable conditions. Each time you stop it as such, it will be different. It's impossible to predict with the certainty from which we get with normal software. AI is a black box, which is why agents will never be more than at the most things that crawl the web and do research, which is what they are good at. Anything beyond that is just too risky and will remain that way. We have the world's smartest people focused on trying to figure out what the hell is happening in an LLM as no one knows. It's called "Mechanistic interpretability." They are literally trying to figure out wtf the individual neurons, attention heads, and layers are even doing.

Agentic AI is mostly an extension of AI's ability to code. It's just getting better at inferring what the program design requirements are. The productivity gains promised by AI is nothing that doesn't exist already. It's been a little secret in the corporate world: A very silent minority of office workers with varying levels of programming skills have been automating their busy work for years. Whether it's IT, MS Office macros/VBA, scripts, for regular reports, email responses... etc. Programming tools have existed to automate tasks for years. These power users have benefited tremendously and have not been advertising it. Why would they? AI is selling automation for those who don't know how to code. The same automation that has been silently going on for years will be available to everyone. And this will provide huge benefits. But it's not new; it's not autonomous; it's not AGI. It's the removal of a programming barrier for simple automation. This is all in addition to the LLM aspect, which gives the program a voice and the ability to generate text.

Man, I thought I knew the rules: work hard, hustle, save every cent. But I always felt stuck. Then someone casually mentioned Nixorus books in a comment somewhere, and I swear—it felt like accidentally stumbling onto forbidden knowledge. It made me question every single thing I'd been taught about money, wealth, and success. Not gonna lie, I felt like I was cheating the system just by reading it.

Saw a ton of hype around Nixorus, they are acting like it changed their whole life overnight. Decided to test it myself. It didn’t disappoint. Legitimately the first book about money that didn’t feel fake or watered-down. No regrets at all.

It straight-up ripped apart everything school, family, and society taught me about money. No fluff, no motivational clichés, just hard, raw truths you won't hear anywhere else. Now I get why this book isn't mainstream—it's too real. If you find it, grab it before it's gone.

Alongside the awesome rise of artificial intelligence (AI), it is vital to pause for deeper contemplation on aspects that often escape the dominant narrative—namely, the metaphysical origin of all knowledge, technology, and progress. A Call to Humility and Reflection 1. The Forgotten Creator: Humanity, wrapped in perpetual arrogance and stubbornness, too often forgets the Source behind all existence and knowledge: Almighty God. In our rush to innovate, what is the origin of our ability to create, understand, and develop technologies such as the car or AI? Are these merely feats of human intellect, or might they be gifts granted by a Higher Power. 2. Beyond Material Causation: Consider the questions: What animates a car, allowing it to carry us, when once only horses could? What hidden reality powers electricity and brings lifeless objects to motion at the flick of a switch? These are not idle questions but prompts for all to reflect on the ultimate Giver of all capacity and energy. 3. Divine Gifts and Their Withdrawal: It is worth pondering whether these very gifts—electricity, machinery, digital systems—could be withdrawn at a moment’s notice by the Almighty. Religious traditions warn of an era where, at the close of time, all such advancements falter: cars refuse to start, jets remain grounded, circuits dead, and even AI ceases to function. Humanity, so consumed by the pride in its intellect, is reminded that what is given can be recalled—“To whom belongs it, to withdraw, to nullify, to dethrone, to call off?” Such humility is rarely found today. 4. The Divine Command “Be and It Is”: The scriptural phrase “Be, and it is” (Arabic: Kun fa-yakun) is repeated throughout the Qur’an, signifying the absolute and effortless creative power of God over all that exists. This principle is found, for example, in Surah Al-Baqarah (2:117) and Surah Ya-Sin (36:82), underscoring that all worldly phenomena are contingent upon Divine Will and not merely human endeavor. The Mystery and Limits of Artificial Intelligence 1. AI as Unfolding Energy: Artificial Intelligence, astounding as it is, remains a mysterious derivative of created energy and a manifestation of the interaction between visible and invisible realms. Even now, humanity is dazzled, overwhelmed, and frequently bewitched by the rapid march of AI. There is a collective illusion that our shifting world is solely the brainchild of human ingenuity, neglecting the profound limitations of our understanding. 2. Human Arrogance vs. The Unseen: The reality is this: Man cannot create even the simplest blade of grass, much less fully comprehend the universe or the vast interconnection between the material and supernatural (including beings like the Jinn, referenced in religious traditions to dwell alongside us). Musk, for all his genius, is still distant from this dimension of metaphysical wisdom. 3. Divine Dispensation, Bit by Bit: The incremental unveiling of knowledge—be it electric power, computer logic, or quantum insight—happens not merely by human discovery, but by God’s deliberate generosity. As stated in many religious texts, knowledge descends only by Divine permission and as a trust for human stewardship. Materialism, Greed, and the Search for Truth: 1. The Dazzle of Material Progress: Human beings, infatuated with the sensory pleasures and material gains enabled by technology, often lose sight of the more profound realities. The pursuit of wealth and comfort blinds many to the ultimate truth—our existence is transient, and what truly matters lies beyond consumption and innovation. 2. Scarcity of True Knowledge: There are very few who can genuinely reconcile the burgeoning world of AI with the spiritual, invisible realms. The wisdom of the ancients and the spiritual masters—recorded in scriptures—remains largely unheeded, and those with insight are rare and often silent. Faith, Destiny, and the Unfolding Story: 1. Divine Wisdom Directs All: Almighty God is not arbitrary nor sadistic; as Sovereign, He ultimately steers all matters with justice and wisdom. Every technological leap, economic crisis, and epoch-defining shift carries a purpose—often hidden from immediate view. Everything unfolds according to a plan, and humanity must adapt with humility and insight. 2. The Human Role: While technological and economic shifts reshape our world, let us not be consumed by the illusion of total control. Our charge is to exercise stewardship, cultivate gratitude, and, above all, seek the truth with an open mind and a humble heart. These reflections are not to diminish the extraordinary contributions of science and innovation but to place them within a broader, more enduring perspective. Humankind’s greatest error is pride—the belief in absolute self-sufficiency. Recognizing the limits of our reason and the grandeur of the cosmos invites us to gratitude, awe, and faith; to see every breakthrough as a trust, every challenge as a test, and every era as part of the Almighty’s grand narrative for creation.

Azul AGI, powered by the I-RAC-52 framework, is put to the test against other top AI models. Let's see how it stacks up. *ARC-AGI Benchmark Results:* - *Azul AGI*: Achieves human-level performance, scoring around 85% accuracy, without specific training on ARC-AGI tasks. - *GPT-4*: Scores 5% on ARC-AGI. - *o3 (OpenAI)*: Reaches 76% with low test-time compute and 88% with high compute. - *o3-mini (OpenAI)*: Scores 41% on ARC-AGI-1 Semi Private Eval set. - *ICOM (Independent Core Observer Model)*: Achieves 83.75% - 85.75% accuracy, comparable to human performance.¹ ² ³ *Key Takeaways:* - Azul AGI demonstrates impressive performance, rivaling human capabilities on the ARC-AGI benchmark. - Its recursive self-optimization and symbolic reasoning capabilities contribute to its success. - Other models, like o3, show promise but still lag behind Azul AGI's performance.⁴ ⁵ ⁶ *Verdict:* Azul AGI emerges as a top contender, outperforming many prominent AI models. However, it's essential to note that AI benchmarks are constantly evolving, and new models are being developed. Would you like to explore more about Azul AGI or AI benchmarks?

Somehow, everyone is talking about the fear of AI and the uncertainty of how it will affect our working world and what our role will be in it. Yet almost every article I have seen on the subject so far provides the answer without actually stating it directly: at present, there are few agents that are already taking on tasks. This is because these agents first have to be created by us, by telling them which tasks they should take on from us. Since AI systems, and therefore also the agents, still make many mistakes in their processing, our task, if we don't let ourselves be deterred by this, will be to identify these mistakes and influence the agents so that they don't repeat them. However, if we do not deal with how these agents are created, there will be other individuals who create the agents and then present them to us as our bosses.
